lines.text: Enter a Servant and PANDARUS

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Friend, you! pray you, a word: do not you follow the young Lord Paris?

lines.speaker: servant
lines.text: Ay, sir, when he goes before me.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: You depend upon him, I mean?

lines.speaker: servant
lines.text: Sir, I do depend upon the lord.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: You depend upon a noble gentleman; I must needs praise him.

lines.speaker: servant
lines.text: The lord be praised!

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: You know me, do you not?

lines.speaker: servant
lines.text: Faith, sir, superficially.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Friend, know me better; I am the Lord Pandarus.

lines.speaker: servant
lines.text: I hope I shall know your honour better.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: I do desire it.

lines.speaker: servant
lines.text: You are in the state of grace.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Grace! not so, friend: honour and lordship are my titles. What music is this?
Music within

lines.speaker: servant
lines.text: I do but partly know, sir: it is music in parts.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Know you the musicians?

lines.speaker: servant
lines.text: Wholly, sir.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Who play they to?

lines.speaker: servant
lines.text: To the hearers, sir.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: At whose pleasure, friend

lines.speaker: servant
lines.text: At mine, sir, and theirs that love music.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Command, I mean, friend.

lines.speaker: servant
lines.text: Who shall I command, sir?

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Friend, we understand not one another: I am too courtly and thou art too cunning. At whose request do these men play?

lines.speaker: servant
lines.text: That's to 't indeed, sir: marry, sir, at the request of Paris my lord, who's there in person; with him, the mortal Venus, the heart-blood of beauty, love's invisible soul,--

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Who, my cousin Cressida?

lines.speaker: servant
lines.text: No, sir, Helen: could you not find out that by her attributes?

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: It should seem, fellow, that thou hast not seen the Lady Cressida. I come to speak with Paris from the Prince Troilus: I will make a complimental assault upon him, for my business seethes.

lines.speaker: servant
lines.text: Sodden business! there's a stewed phrase indeed!
Enter PARIS and HELEN, attended

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Fair be to you, my lord, and to all this fair company! fair desires, in all fair measure, fairly guide them! especially to you, fair queen! fair thoughts be your fair pillow!

lines.speaker: helen
lines.text: Dear lord, you are full of fair words.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: You speak your fair pleasure, sweet queen. Fair prince, here is good broken music.

lines.speaker: paris
lines.text: You have broke it, cousin: and, by my life, you shall make it whole again; you shall piece it out with a piece of your performance. Nell, he is full of harmony.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Truly, lady, no.

lines.speaker: helen
lines.text: O, sir,--

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Rude, in sooth; in good sooth, very rude.

lines.speaker: paris
lines.text: Well said, my lord! well, you say so in fits.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: I have business to my lord, dear queen. My lord, will you vouchsafe me a word?

lines.speaker: helen
lines.text: Nay, this shall not hedge us out: we'll hear you sing, certainly.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Well, sweet queen. you are pleasant with me. But, marry, thus, my lord: my dear lord and most esteemed friend, your brother Troilus,--

lines.speaker: helen
lines.text: My Lord Pandarus; honey-sweet lord,--

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Go to, sweet queen, to go:--commends himself most affectionately to you,--

lines.speaker: helen
lines.text: You shall not bob us out of our melody: if you do, our melancholy upon your head!

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Sweet queen, sweet queen! that's a sweet queen, i' faith.

lines.speaker: helen
lines.text: And to make a sweet lady sad is a sour offence.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Nay, that shall not serve your turn; that shall not, in truth, la. Nay, I care not for such words; no, no. And, my lord, he desires you, that if the king call for him at supper, you will make his excuse.

lines.speaker: helen
lines.text: My Lord Pandarus,--

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: What says my sweet queen, my very very sweet queen?

lines.speaker: paris
lines.text: What exploit's in hand? where sups he to-night?

lines.speaker: helen
lines.text: Nay, but, my lord,--

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: What says my sweet queen? My cousin will fall out with you. You must not know where he sups.

lines.speaker: paris
lines.text: I'll lay my life, with my disposer Cressida.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: No, no, no such matter; you are wide: come, your disposer is sick.

lines.speaker: paris
lines.text: Well, I'll make excuse.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Ay, good my lord. Why should you say Cressida? no, your poor disposer's sick.

lines.speaker: paris
lines.text: I spy.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: You spy! what do you spy? Come, give me an instrument. Now, sweet queen.

lines.speaker: helen
lines.text: Why, this is kindly done.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: My niece is horribly in love with a thing you have, sweet queen.

lines.speaker: helen
lines.text: She shall have it, my lord, if it be not my lord Paris.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: He! no, she'll none of him; they two are twain.

lines.speaker: helen
lines.text: Falling in, after falling out, may make them three.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Come, come, I'll hear no more of this; I'll sing you a song now.

lines.speaker: helen
lines.text: Ay, ay, prithee now. By my troth, sweet lord, thou hast a fine forehead.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Ay, you may, you may.

lines.speaker: helen
lines.text: Let thy song be love: this love will undo us all. O Cupid, Cupid, Cupid!

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Love! ay, that it shall, i' faith.

lines.speaker: paris
lines.text: Ay, good now, love, love, nothing but love.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: In good troth, it begins so. Love, love, nothing but love, still more! For, O, love's bow Shoots buck and doe: The shaft confounds, Not that it wounds, But tickles still the sore. These lovers cry Oh! oh! they die! Yet that which seems the wound to kill, Doth turn oh! oh! to ha! ha! he! So dying love lives still: Oh! oh! a while, but ha! ha! ha! Oh! oh! groans out for ha! ha! ha! Heigh-ho!
Sings

lines.speaker: helen
lines.text: In love, i' faith, to the very tip of the nose.

lines.speaker: paris
lines.text: He eats nothing but doves, love, and that breeds hot blood, and hot blood begets hot thoughts, and hot thoughts beget hot deeds, and hot deeds is love.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Is this the generation of love? hot blood, hot thoughts, and hot deeds? Why, they are vipers: is love a generation of vipers? Sweet lord, who's a-field to-day?

lines.speaker: paris
lines.text: Hector, Deiphobus, Helenus, Antenor, and all the gallantry of Troy: I  would fain have armed to-day, but my Nell would not have it so. How chance my brother Troilus went not?

lines.speaker: helen
lines.text: He hangs the lip at something: you know all, Lord Pandarus.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Not I, honey-sweet queen. I long to hear how they sped to-day. You'll remember your brother's excuse?

lines.speaker: paris
lines.text: To a hair.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Farewell, sweet queen.

lines.speaker: helen
lines.text: Commend me to your niece.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: I will, sweet queen.
Exit
A retreat sounded

lines.speaker: paris
lines.text: They're come from field: let us to Priam's hall, To greet the warriors. Sweet Helen, I must woo you To help unarm our Hector: his stubborn buckles, With these your white enchanting fingers touch'd, Shall more obey than to the edge of steel Or force of Greekish sinews; you shall do more Than all the island kings,--disarm great Hector.

lines.speaker: helen
lines.text: 'Twill make us proud to be his servant, Paris; Yea, what he shall receive of us in duty Gives us more palm in beauty than we have, Yea, overshines ourself.

lines.speaker: paris
lines.text: Sweet, above thought I love thee.
Exeunt
